head.citation-title: Cellular immunological responses to silk materials
head.abstracts: In vivo inclusion of polymers from both synthetic and biological sources, as evident in biomedical applications such as in drug delivery and tissue engineering, introduces interaction with the host immune system. Such issue is of primary significance that requires critical consideration prior to the application. Unfortunate cases have been encountered when materials with excellent physical, mechanical and biological activities are rejected from the studies on the basis of their immunological responses as evident in allergic and inflammatory manifestation that can lead to treatment failure. Therefore, it is important for the innate immune responses to any biomaterials to be thoroughly investigated as critical criteria for their potential applications. Being protein, both sericin and fibroin, silk possesses a likelihood of being an immunological activator. Additionally, different extraction methods yield fibroin and sericin with contamination of trace amounts of their degradation products. Consideration must be given to affinity and binding properties of these trace elements in relation to cellular mediators of inflammation that may influence the host biological responses. It is noteworthy that controversy over the host immunological interactions following exposure to silk materials has been reported. This immunological issue should therefore be resolved prior to human application. © 2012 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

coredata.dc:description: In vivo inclusion of polymers from both synthetic and biological sources, as evident in biomedical applications such as in drug delivery and tissue engineering, introduces interaction with the host immune system. Such issue is of primary significance that requires critical consideration prior to the application. Unfortunate cases have been encountered when materials with excellent physical, mechanical and biological activities are rejected from the studies on the basis of their immunological responses as evident in allergic and inflammatory manifestation that can lead to treatment failure. Therefore, it is important for the innate immune responses to any biomaterials to be thoroughly investigated as critical criteria for their potential applications. Being protein, both sericin and fibroin, silk possesses a likelihood of being an immunological activator. Additionally, different extraction methods yield fibroin and sericin with contamination of trace amounts of their degradation products. Consideration must be given to affinity and binding properties of these trace elements in relation to cellular mediators of inflammation that may influence the host biological responses. It is noteworthy that controversy over the host immunological interactions following exposure to silk materials has been reported. This immunological issue should therefore be resolved prior to human application. © 2012 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:title: Cellular immunological responses to silk materials
